titleStmt.title: Vox militis foreshewing what perils are procured where the people of this, or any other kingdome liue without regard of marshall discipline, especially when they stand and behold their friends in apparent danger, and almost subuerted by there enemies vniust persecution, and yet with hold their helping hand and assistance. Diuided into two parts, the first manifesting for what causes princes may enter into warre, and how necessary and vsuall it is, drawne from the actions of the Prince of Orange. The second discourseth of warre, souldiers, and the time when it is conuenient: collected out of the heroicall examples of Count Mansfield. ... Dedicated to Count Mansfield, and the honourable Councell of Warre.
titleStmt.author: Marcelline, George.
Rich, Barnabe, 1540?-1617. Allarme to England.

publicationStmt.publisher: By B[ernard] A[lsop] for Thomas Archer, and are to bee sold at his shop in Popes head Alley, ouer against the signe of the Horse-shoe,

notesStmt.note: Dedication signed: G.M., i.e. George Marcelline.

An adaptation of "Allarme to England" by Barnabe Rich. Much of the book exactly reprints Rich's work; Marcelline omits passages relating to contemporary events, replacing them with others of a similar nature.
In this state the first quire has four leaves.
The last two leaves are blank.
Reproduction of the original in the Folger Shakespeare Library.

place.placeName: his shop in Popes head Alley, ouer against the signe of the Horse-shoe
